title.narrative: Prog2017-2021_commun_ASE-OS: About 200.000 organised marginalised workers in Cambodia, Vietnam and Laos, in particular women, can exert their rights and increase their economic and social resilience by influencing the relevant decision makers to expand, finance and deliver social protection more effectively and equitably.

description.narrative: About 200.000 organised marginalised workers in Cambodia, Vietnam and Laos, in particular women, can exert their rights and increase their economic and social resilience by influencing the relevant decision makers to expand, finance and deliver social protection more effectively and equitably

Region: AMRC: currently 21 members in the regional network AROSP, coming from 14 different countries. Plans to increase to 31 members by 2021, and adding 1 more country: Malaysia. Cambodia: CFSWF: Currently 15 grassroots workers’ organisations in the general service sector, entertainment sector, food and brewing sectors (incl. beer and cigarette promotion work), work in supermarkets, gasoline stations, and waste collection. By 2021 plans for 57 local groups. Us: 8 local groups of garment workers and sex workers. Plans to increase membership and 6 additional groups. YRDP: Currently no local organised groups of youngsters/students (18 to 30 y. old) working in informal economy or volunteers in NGOs. Plans to increase to about 45 groups by 2021. CCFC: Currently 37 local Farmers Groups (80% female). Plans to increase to 40 groups by 2021. C.CAWDU: Currently 3 groups of informal garment workers, plans to increase to 25 by 2012. IDEA: Currently 33 local groups to be increased to 39 local groups in 2021. Vietnam: CDI: Currently 12 local clubs of migrant workers; a mix of formal and informal workers. Plans to increase to 16 groups, organised in 2 networks. LIGHT:12 local groups of street- and scrap-vendors, and domestic workers (per hour work). Plans to increase to 20. GFCD: works with8 domestic workers/women’s groups and aim at 15 groups by 2021,organised in 1 association.SDRC: plans to organise 10 waste collectors groups and 10 associations by 2021.M-net: a network with currently 6 members, aiming at 14 member, 1 leader association and § workers’ groups Laos:LFTU: currently 68 local trade unions in the sectors of garment, plastics, metal and wool processing manufacturing, mining, and 28 in the informal sector: home-based, construction, plantations, waste collection, street vending and services. Plans to increase to about 238 local unions in formal sector and 53 in the informal economy by 2021. ECCDA: 5 local groups of waste collectors, home-based workers and migrants. Plans to increase to 22 by 2021.HNL: Currently 2 home-based workers’ groups, plans to increase to 10 groups by 2012.CAMKID: no target groups in 2016; plans to increase to 12 groups by 2021. In all, there are 269 target groups at the start of this programme, to be increased to 682 target groups by 2021.

This program contributes to the thematic Joint Strategic Framework Decent Work, in particular Sub-target III (Expanding Social protection for all) and Sub-target IV (Promoting Social Dialogue for all).

This programme builds on the 2014-16 programme in the ASEAN region to promote social protection for an increasingly vulnerable group in Cambodia, Vietnam and Laos, namely marginalised workers. At local level the programme obtained encouraging successes. Now the focus will also be put on increased effectiveness of national advocacy for more inclusive social protection frameworks, implemented by capacitated citizens who will exert their rights. We will obtain national impact by using a combination of strategies: (1) working with a wider constituency covering more than 774 marginalised workers’ groups, (2) creation of national and widely supported advocacy coalitions for specific demands for social protection, (3) ensuring that representatives are empowered for social dialogue thanks to credible arguments, competences and members’ support, (4) ability to grasp or create advocacy opportunities via media, public campaigns and lobby-work, supported by a power and stakeholder analysis, (5) cooperation across borders in regional networks to jointly monitor the roll out of the ASEAN Action Plan for Social Protection, (6) a joint focus on 3 crucial issues: increased inclusiveness, reduced gender gap and increased financing of social protection, and (7) use of peer pressure amongst ASEAN countries resulting from the ASEAN Action Plan. We will work with 15 partners in 3 countries and with 1 regional network, all supported by 6 stakeholders that bring expertise, competences or capacity building. We expect positive impact in terms of increased social and economic resilience for about 200.000 citizens.

participating-org.narrative: Cambodian Food and Service Workers Federation
Center for Social Work and Community Development Research and Consultancy
Coalition of Cambodia Apparel Worker Democratic Union
Environment Conservation and Community Development Association
Indepedant Democracy of Informal Economy Association
Institute for Developmen and Community Health
Research Center for Gender, Family and Community Development

name.narrative: South East Asia (Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, Regional)

description.narrative: South East Asia (Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, Regional)

title.narrative: Prog2017-2021_commun_ASE-OS: About 200.000 organised marginalised workers in Cambodia, Vietnam and Laos, in particular women, can exert their rights and increase their economic and social resilience by influencing the relevant decision makers to expand, finance and deliver social protection more effectively and equitably.
Number of national SP policies amended or created in Laos that imply an increase in government budget (accumulated)

comment.narrative: Health Insurance /Universal healthcare scheme, 2015

- Unemployment fund and sick leave benefits for COVID covered under the NSSF - National Health Insurance: free treatment for COVID patients, - Social Protection pilot for informal economy workers in Xekhong province, allowing 1,079 workers to access the social security fund

title.narrative: Number of national SP policies amended or created in Laos that are in favour of women. (accumulated)

description.narrative: Verification source: Baseline, mid-term and end-line survey of relevant policies amended or created

comment.narrative: Mother and child care
- Government funded the 1000 day protection campaign for mothers & children in Vientiane province and an awareness building campaign in 2020 - The domestic workers policy is being drafted by MoLSW
Government funded the 1000 day protection campaign for mothers & children in Vientiane province and announced an awareness building campaign in 2020

title.narrative: Number of national SP policies amended or created in Cambodia that imply an increase in government budget (accumulated)

comment.narrative: NSPS-National Social Protection Strategy for the Poor and Vulnerable 2011-2015

- NSPPF-National Social Protection Policy Framework (2016-2025); - Inter-Ministral Prakas 404-The implementation of healthcare through Health Equity Funds for Informal Workers and Bonus Allowance for Women Workers during Baby Delivery (11th October 2017) - The Notification #142/20 on the process to register informal economy workers to the NSSF for Health Equity Fund via the unions recognized by the MoLVT. - MoLVT issued Guideline #336 on the Registration of the Informal Workers to the NSSF so that all workers, including informal workers, can access NSSF Revision and endorsement on NSSF law - Cash Transfer Program for Mother and Children Under 2 Year Old (June 2019) - New Social Security Law signed in 2019, which includes domestic workers and self-employed. The conditions, formalities and procedures of the implementation of the Law are regulated by sub-degrees.

title.narrative: Number of national SP policies amended or created in Cambodia in favour of the informal workers (accumulated)

description.narrative: Verification source: Baseline, mid-term and end-line survey of relevant policies amended or created

comment.narrative: NSSF to cover universal health coverage for informal sector

- Informal workers included in the overall SP Policy framework - Inter-Ministerial PRAKAS NO. 404 LV/PrK.NSSF on the Implementation of Health Care through the Health Equity Fund System for Informal Workers and Provision of Allowance for Female Workers after giving birth. - MoLVT issued Guideline #336 on the Registration of the Informal Workers to the NSSF so that all workers, including informal workers, can access NSSF. - Prakas #235 on Work Conditions of Domestic Workers related to working hours, work contracts between employers and employees, weekly day off, and national and international holidays leave. - New Social Security Law signed in 2019, which includes domestic workers and self-employed. The conditions, formalities and procedures of the implementation of the Law are regulated by sub-degrees. - Draft of New Social Protection Law explicitly mentions the informal workers and self-employed as a group of workers to have access to SP. - Notification #142/20 in 2020 on the process to register informal economy workers to the NSSF for Health Equity Fund via the unions recognized by the MoLVT.
Informal workers included in the overall SP Policy framework, but not yet translated into specific laws, except for Tuktuk drivers and domestic workers who have been allowed under the NSSF

title.narrative: Number of national SP policies amended or created in Laos in favour of the informal workers (accumulated)

description.narrative: Verification source: Baseline, mid-term and end-line survey of relevant policies amended or created

comment.narrative: National social protection strategy to include recommendations from LFTU (Lao Federation of Trade Unions)

- New Government policy target to cover all Informal Workers under NSSF by 2030 - Government target to achieve UHC by 2025 - Lao Trade Union Law amendment in 2017 enabled LFTU to promote the rights of workers in the informal economy - Revision of law on OHS to include informal workers - Approval of the New National Social Protection Strategy 2030 - Amendment of the labour standards and minimum wage for daily workers in Bokeo and Laung nam tha provinces, which includes all domestic workers
New Government policy target to cover all IW under NSSF by 2030 And achieve UHC by 2025 Revision of law on OHS to include informal workers

title.narrative: Number of national SP policies amended or created in Vietnam in favour of the informal workers (accumulated)

description.narrative: Verification source: Baseline, mid-term and end-line survey of relevant policies amended or created

comment.narrative: New occupational health and safety law promulgated in 2015 that covers informal workers

- Informal workers have been included in the 2019 revision of the labour code, paving the way to way to equal protection - Covid19 Response Policy which provides cash support for a number of groups of informal workers, - Voluntary social insurance policy which will potentially include the informal workers is being under review
Informal workers have been included in the 2019 revision of the labour code, paving the way to way to equal protection

title.narrative: Number of national SP policies amended or created in Cambodia that are in favour of women. (accumulated)

description.narrative: Verification source: Baseline, mid-term and end-line survey of relevant policies amended or created

comment.narrative: Specific childcare provision for women workers

- Inclusion of Domestic Workers in the NSSF - Prakas #235 on Work Conditions of Domestic Workers related to working hours, work contracts between employers and employees, weekly day off, and national and international holidays leave. - Inter-Ministerial PRAKAS NO. 404 LV/PrK.NSSF on the Implementation of Health Care through the Health Equity Fund System for Informal Workers and Provision of Allowance for Female Workers after giving birth. - New Social Security Law signed in 2019, which includes domestic workers and self-employed. The conditions, formalities and procedures of the implementation of the Law are regulated by sub-degrees
Inclusion of Domestic Workers in the NSSF

title.narrative: Number of national SP policies amended or created in Vietnam that are in favour of women. (accumulated)

description.narrative: Verification source: Baseline, mid-term and end-line survey of relevant policies amended or created

comment.narrative: Specific policy for women workers

- Baseline: Baseline – (specific policy for women workers) - Revised definition of sexual harassment in the workplace included in the 2019 labour code revision - Revision of the voluntary social insurance, which will potentially include the maternity benefits in favor of women informal workers.
Revised definition of sexual harassment in the workplace included in the 2019 labour code revision

title.narrative: Number of national SP policies amended or created in Vietnam that imply an increase in government budget (accumulated)

comment.narrative: - Revision of the voluntary social insurance, anticipating an increase in the national budget to extend the coverage to informal economy workers
